million dollars in funding so when we first started it was a real simple order form and this
is all we had copy and paste and upload some text upload a file uh you immediately get a
quote if you're translating from English uh or sort of word-based languages then we just calculate how many words in the

and as we looked at the content coming into the system uh we noticed in

spread more than half of the type of content we do is under 500 Words
so we noticed that it turns out an API integration is really something that
makes sense for platforms that have this high volume of short form content so an API
uh you know allows sort of Integrations of systems to simplify the flow and ordering of translation
and so we after we launched the order form we noticed this trend in the type of content we we sort of rejiggered it
and turned it into an API to allow other platforms to integrate and we now have a
couple um examples some these are some of the highlights and so pixel on the left is a sort of like a
Japanese version of Shutterstock so Shutterstock is a US listed multi-billion dollar company where they just

France and they are a platform that helps resell uh use luxury clothing so
you've got your expensive jacket or your shoes you never want to you don't want to wear anymore still a high value item
and so the seller types the description in French and puts it in a package and
sends it off to the Paris office and I had an opportunity to go visit they've got this seven step process where they validate and check that it's not a fake
and make sure it's clean and all that and if it's all good then they package it and they flip a switch and that turns
the item first on for sale and that triggers in their system the sending of
the French original French description through the API to our platform and our translators will grab the text and
translate it into English and then when they click submit it gets sent back to the of SDR system and that's now it's
available for the English-speaking Community to buy as well and so creates a lot more liquidity for vastier
and the cus the sellers are happy larger audience the customer is happy they have access to more products and we also have
a YouTube integration where if you upload a video with captions
uh the you'll you'll see sort of a button that says translate this and then you choose your target languages and

most you know a traditional translation agency would not be able to handle that sort of flow
so how do we actually manage uh the translators
this is really core to to our platform uh and it starts with an internal team
we call Tops or the translator operations team it's about four individuals and they are tasked with for
each language pair that we support hiring a senior translator and that senior translator is responsible for
their language pair and they create tests they manage they evaluate the tests and they are sort of like a
moderator for the for the language pair and as we advertise on a platform like Facebook for individuals who are
bilingual who are interested in working on Gango we've managed to get about 10
000 translators who have passed and qualified uh to become a Gango translator now the testing is pretty
difficult if you're a bilingual yourself you're welcome to give it a try don't get upset with me if you don't pass but
there's over a hundred thousand individuals who've tried so less than 10 percent actually become a Gango
translator it's pretty challenging uh but it's really important for us to
to nurture this base of translators and so we create a lot of materials uh
for translators to to sort of work uh and improve and work up the system so
um over 50 of individuals on our of the translators on our platform are not uh
professional translators they're bilingual individuals some of them are many of them are students
um and so there's uh they're not as familiar with some of the translator tools
um aspects around time management they've never really worked freelance before and so we create documentation
for them uh to educate them um under these uh under these topics so you've got the the art of revision
um making text sound natural of course language is a living thing right and so
um how do you translate new words new terminology how do you stay with pop culture and how does that you know
translate uh pun intended to another language right so um we we this is really important for us
so once you become a translator you get access to a dashboard and on this dashboard is when the jobs
come in it's a first come first serve system so uh you have to be pretty quick
um but there's a lot of flexibility flexibility you can choose which jobs you want to do you can look at how long
it's going to take you can see how much content there is that you're going to have to translate so you can sort of adjust with the available time that you
have in the day and we also try and be very transparent about how our system is evaluating the
translators uh and so I mentioned the senior translators they have internal tools themselves for spot checking and
evaluating the translation output from each of these translators and before it goes back to customer a senior
translator will check it and give it a score and so we reveal uh sort of the
translator's reputation in the system to each individual translator so they can see their quality and of course speed is
also really important most of our customers are trying to sell something online they're trying to get out to an audience as quick as they can uh and so
the translators start to get accustomed to uh sort of balancing this this
quality versus speed and there's sort of a nice equilibrium so overseeing all of this is that tops
team that I mentioned and their focus is on sort of three pillars their speed
quality and scale and a number of parameters go into each one uh and what we've done is is created
this sort of language pair Health index which is kind of like a GDP for a language pair and so there's like a all
these parameters get put into some equation and outcomes in a single number and if that number gets below a certain
threshold then we know there's a problem for that language pair and the tops team goes in and tries to figure out which of
the parameters are actually impacting it in a negative way and they try and fix that fix that issue and and bring the
number above threshold again so um that's kind of a a pretty cerebral or
analytical way of how we manage the crowd
